III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Medical and dental care policy
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413
Section
Description • (1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following:
(a) The provision of routine medical care.
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated.
(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation MDHHS policies have consistently been disregarded, proper care
for medically fragile child has not been provided and/or followed
through which has resulted in abuse/neglect of a foster child.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed on 3/5/2024 and 3/13/2024 via
telephone. The Complainant reported the same information as
the allegations in both interviews. Policies and procedures have
consistently been disregarded, proper care for medically fragile
child has not been provided and/or followed through.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via Microsoft Teams
on 3/13/2024. He reported the staff on the case will assist in this
investigation. He was attentive during the information sharing and
was an active participate in the discussion of the allegations.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on 3/13/2024 via
Microsoft Teams. She provided background history on Youth A’s
case and reported she was assigned Youth A’s case on
11/2/2022. In summary, the FCW reported Youth A and his
siblings were removed from their home on 2/20/2020.
The FCW reported Youth A is placed with his biological father and
Youth A has been placed there since October 6, 2021. The FCW
reported there are no current safety concerns with Youth A’s
placement. She reported Youth A’s medical issues are addressed
and up to date as well as Youth A’s other services he is provided.
She reported she makes monthly visits to the biological father’s
2

home and Youth A is doing well in the home. The FCW reported
she discussed with the father, Youth A’s medical needs during her
monthly visitations.
The FCW reported a DHHS investigation was initiated on
December 26, 2023, on the biological father for medical neglect of
Youth A. She said there was no evidence to support the
allegations on the biological father. The FCW reported the
biological father’s home remains the best interest of Youth A
because he is also placed with his half-sister. The FCW said
Youth A continues to adjust and thrive since being placed with his
biological father. The FCW reported Youth A and his biological
father continue to improve their relationship as they participate in
Early Childhood and Infant Mental Health Services. The FCW said
Youth A’s biological father is willing and able to meet all of Youth
A's needs including any health needs that may arise. The FCW
reported the biological father is in the process of gaining full
custody of Youth A.
Documentation Review:
• MiSACWIS information was reviewed on Youth A’s medical
history. Documentation indicates Youth A’s DOB 6/4/2018,
last physical examination was completed on 10/19/2023,
with no medical concerns and his last dental examination
was completed on 9/1/2023. Youth A’s medical history is
as follows: Youth A was born 23 weeks premature and
was in neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). Youth A was
born with bronchopulmonary dysplasia which requires his
oxygen levels are checked 2 times per day. Youth A was a
little over a year old when he entered foster care. Youth A
came into care with oxygen and a feeding tube. Youth A
was eventually taken off the oxygen and the feeding tube
was removed on 06/23/2021. Youth A participates in
individual trauma-based therapy, play therapy, and family
therapy with his biological father. Youth A is seen by a
psychiatrist and is prescribed Guanfacine 1MG once a day
for ADHD and Albuterol for Asthma which is used as
needed. Medical documentation in MiSACWIS indicates
Youth A is up to date on his medical and dental
examinations.
• DHHS investigation report dated 12/26/2023 reported
allegations as medical neglect and physical injury. The
findings were as follows: “Youth A is considered a
vulnerable 5-year-old child diagnosed with ADHD. There
3

are no unmet medical, mental health, or safety needs. The
medical practitioner reported there are no abnormal
findings, and that Youth A is up to date on all of his shots.
No concerns regarding medical neglect.” Concerns
regarding potential child abuse and/or neglect, there is no
concern regarding abuse and/or neglect of Youth A.
Regarding physical injury, there were no marks or bruises
observed on Youth A’s face, legs, arms, stomach, or back.
Nothing appeared to be in the healing stage.”
• MiSACWIS social work contacts were reviewed. The social
work contacts indicated the FCW is in the home monthly
completing visitations with Youth A and his biological
father.
• Medical and dental policy. This policy was reviewed, and
the agency is following their policy on routine and medical
and dental care as well as making sure Youth A is up to
date with his physical and dental examinations.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as the FCW, per social work
contacts, is in the home monthly to visit with Youth A and his
biological father. No medical concerns were noted. The agency is
following their medical and dental policy. Youth A’s last physical
examination was completed on 10/19.2023 and his last dental
examination was 9/1/2023. The DHHS investigation report found
no evidence of medical neglect.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
4

Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA 400.12421
Section
Description • (3) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact
between parents and children except where parental
rights have been terminated or where there is a court
determination that visits are detrimental to the child.
Violation Type Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Allegation Agency allowed father who was initially a respondent on the
abuse/neglect case to change parenting time and violate court
order.
5

Investigation Complainant was interviewed on 3/5/2024 and 3/13/2024 via
telephone. The Complainant reported the same information as
the allegations in both interviews. It was reported by the
Complainant the agency allowed the father who was initially a
respondent on the abuse/neglect case to change parenting time
and violate a court order. The Complainant added the biological
father of Youth A was not allowing Youth A’s Mother to see or visit
with Youth A and the agency is not scheduling a Family Team
Meeting (FTM).
It was noted a FTM was scheduled for Friday, March 15, 2024.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams on 3/13/2024. She reported this is a pattern of Youth A’s
Mother and the allegations reported had been investigated by a
DHHS Worker and there was no evidence to support the
allegations. The FCS reported Youth A’s Mother’s allegations
occurs when there is an upcoming court hearing or when she is
missing her children. The FCS provided the DHHS Worker
investigation findings. This report will be discussed later in this
report.
The Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on 3/13/2024
via Microsoft Teams. She reported there are no current safety
concerns with Youth A’s placement. She reported she visits the
biological father’s home on a monthly basis to discuss Youth A’s
treatment plan, and Youth A’s other services he is provided.
The FCW reported at this time the biological father is not willing to
allow Youth A to visit with Youth A’s Mother and the father has not
allowed the FCW to pick Youth A up for his mother’s visitations.
The FCW reported the father is aware that he is not following
court orders, and he stated he understands he is not following
court orders, and the court is aware of the situation between him
and Youth A’s Mother. The FCW reported the father reported
Youth A’s safety is his only concern.
The FCW reported the court-ordered services are as follows:
trauma assessment for the children which is being followed.
Youth A’s Mother is required to complete/comply with parenting
classes, substance abuse treatment, individual therapy, a
psychological evaluation conducted, and if recommended, a
psychiatric. Submit to weekly random drug screens, obtain a
legal income and suitable housing, visit the children, maintain
contact with the worker, and attend all court hearings. The FCW
said as of 3/13/2024, Youth A’s Mother has completed parenting
6

classes, individual therapy, and psychological evaluation and has
suitable housing. FCW reported Youth A’s Mother has not
submitted drug screens since September of 2023 and the
children’s safety and well-being could remain at risk due to
circumstances that led the children coming into care. The FCW
reported Youth A’s Mother and Youth A are court-ordered
parenting visits to be supervised at the MDHHS office only. The
FCW reported Youth A’s Mother has not been consistent with her
parenting visits.
The FCW reported Youth A’s Mother was having unsupervised
overnight visits with Youth A from Friday – Sunday. However, on
Monday, February 6, 2023, the FCW received information from
Youth A’s father that Youth A’s Mother did not return Youth A
back to his father after the parenting visit. After numerous
attempts and no response, the FCW said she was able to contact
Youth A’s Mother by phone. She reported Youth A, and his
mother was located at the domestic shelter. She said the police
accompanied her to the domestic shelter and she was able to
complete a wellbeing check on Youth A. The FCW reported
Youth A’s Mother alleged she did not answer her telephone
because it was turned off. She reported Youth A’s Mother also
informed her that she did not feel comfortable taking Youth A
back to his father’s home. The FCW said she explained to Youth
A’s Mother that she cannot keep Youth A with her and that she
had to return Youth A back to his father. The FCW said Youth A’s
Mother returned Youth A back to his father on 2/7/2023.
The FCW reported a similar incident occurred again on February
20, 2023. The FCW reported on Tuesday, 2/21/2023, she met
with Youth A’s Mother at the doctor’s office with Youth A. The
doctor did not have any concerns but stated Youth A should be
taking his daily medications. After the doctor’s visit, the FCW said
she transported Youth A back to his father’s home.
Documentation Review:
• Updated service plan (USP) dated 11/4/2023 – 2/9/2024
reported the following information: Youth A had consistent
parenting time with Youth A’s Mother from 12/4/2023 –
3/2/2024. Youth A’s parenting time stopped between
Youth A and Youth A’s Mother because of Youth A’s
Mother ’s history of substance abuse and domestic
violence and that he (the father) did not want Youth A to
have contact with Youth A’s Mother for safety reasons. In
the USP, the FCW reported the father reported the courts
7

were aware Youth A’s father is refusing to allow Youth A
visits with Youth A’s Mother. The FCW reported in the
USP that Youth A’s Mother is ordered to complete weekly
random drug screens. However, during this reporting
period, Youth A’s Mother did not complete any drug
screens.
• Social Work contacts in MiSACWIS between Youth A
and Youth A’s Mother is documented as follows:
3/21/2024 – The parenting visit was canceled due to no
contact from the mother contacting the agency FCW to
confirm the visit.
3/28/2024 – The Parenting visit did not occur; Youth A’s
Mother could not be reached by the FCW to confirm
parenting visit for Youth A.
4/4/2024 - The Parenting visit did not occur, Youth A’s
Mother called the FCW and stated she could not get her
car out of the garage.
It is documented that the FCW is making her face-to-face
contacts in the home of Youth A and Youth A’s father
monthly and conducting parenting time visits.
• FCW reported the court hearing held on 3/18/2024,
reported three days of full custody trial. No court order was
finalized, or any agreement made. The trial was continued
until 5/10/2024. The FCW said the Judge on the case
stated the next court hearing will be the last day for trial
and at the end of the trial, a decision about full custody and
parenting time will be made.
Analysis The court order was violated regarding Youth A’s father not
allowing Youth A’s Mother to visit with Youth A. However, in
reviewing the social work contacts, there were three parenting
visits scheduled with Youth A and Youth A’s Mother and all three
parenting time visits did not occur due to Youth A’s Mother not
confirming the visits or having transportation issues. It is unclear
when the father decided to allow Youth A’s Mother to visit with
Youth A per court order. It was documented in social work
contacts there was an FTM held and scheduled for Friday, March
15, 2024.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
